## Organization of the Nervous System

The nervous system is organized into distinct [anatomical]{.highlight} and [functional]{.highlight} divisions.
It is composed of interconnected networks that work in tight coordination to support vital, sensory, emotional, cognitive, and behavioral functions.

::: columns
::: column
> [Anatomical]{.highlight} division classifies the nervous system based on `physical structures` and location

:::
::: column

> [Functional]{.highlight} division classifies the nervous system based on the type of `information` processed

:::
:::

## Anatomical Directions
::: columns
::: column

::: {.nonincremental}
- `Rostral` or `Anterior`: toward the front  
- `Caudal` or `Posterior`: toward the back  
:::

::: {.nonincremental}
- `Dorsal`: toward the top  
- `Ventral`: toward the bottom  
:::

::: {.nonincremental}
- `Medial`: toward the midline  
- `Lateral`: away from the midline
:::

:::
::: column

![](images/SN_org_directions1.png){width="250" fig-align="right"}
![](images/SN_org_directions2.png){width="250" fig-align="right"}

:::
:::

## Anatomical Planes

::: columns
::: column
The Body can be sectioned along three main planes:

- `Sagittal`: Divides left and right halves

- `Coronal`: Divides rostral and caudal parts

- `Horizontal (or Axial or Transverse)`: Divides dorsal and ventral parts

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_planes.jpg){width="300" fig-align="right"}
![](images/SN_org_planes2.png){width="400" fig-align="right"}

:::
:::

## CNS & PNS

::: columns
::: column
The nervous system is classically divided into two main anatomical components:

::: info-box
**Central Nervous System (CNS)**  
Brain and spinal cord  
:::

::: info-box
**Peripheral Nervous System (PNS)**  
Nerves and ganglia outside the CNS  
:::

:::
::: column

## Central Nervous System (CNS)

::: columns
::: column
::: info-box
The CNS includes:

- Brain  
- Spinal cord  
:::

::: info-box
Neurons in the CNS are responsible for:

- Sensory processing  
- Cognitive & Emotional processing 
- Behavioural output  
:::

::: card
The CNS is `protected` by bone, meninges, and cerebrospinal fluid.
:::

:::
::: column
![](images/SN_org_CNS.jpg){width="450" fig-align="right"}
:::
:::

## Peripheral Nervous System (PNS)

::: columns
::: column
The PNS includes:

::: info-box
- Cranial & Spinal nerves  
- Autonomic NS  
- Somatic NS  
:::

> Its main role is `communication` between the body and the CNS.

::: info-box
Information flows in two directions:

- `Afferent`: From body to CNS
- `Efferent`: From CNS to body
:::

::: 
::: column
![](images/SN_org_PNS.jpg){width="500" fig-align="right"}
![](images/SN_org_aff_eff.png){width="400" fig-align="right"}
::: 
::: 

## Somatic nervous system

::: columns
::: column
The **somatic nervous system**:

::: info-box
**Efferent Signals**

- Skeletal muscles  
- Voluntary movement 

:::

::: info-box
**Afferent Signals**

- Skin  
- Muscles and Joints 

This includes the sense of touch, temperature, pain, and [proprioception](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proprioception).
:::



::: 
::: column
> Activity in this system is **usually** under `conscious` perception and `voluntary` control.

![](images/SN_org_reflex_arc.png){width="500" fig-align="right"}

::: 
::: 

## Autonomic nervous system

::: columns
::: column
The **autonomic nervous system** regulates internal physiology.

::: info-box
It controls:

- Vital functions (Heart rate, breathing...) 
- Smooth muscle (Digestion, salivation...)
- Glands (Hormones...) 
:::

> Most autonomic activity occurs `without` conscious awareness.
> It is composed of two main branches: `Sympathetic` and `Parasympathetic`.

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_ANS.jpg){width="470" fig-align="right"}

::: 
::: 

## Sympathetic nervous system

::: columns
::: column

The **sympathetic nervous system** prepares the body for action [Fight or Flight]{.highlight} Response.

:::info-box
Activation of the sympathetic system typically leads to:

- Increased heart rate  
- Bronchodilation  
- Reduced digestive activity  
- Mobilization of glucose  
:::

> Increase the `Arousal` level. These effects support physical and cognitive demands.

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_ANS.jpg){width="470" fig-align="right"}

::: 
::: 

## Parasympathetic nervous system

::: columns
::: column
The **parasympathetic nervous system** promotes maintenance and recovery. [Rest and Digest]{.highlight} Response.

:::info-box
Activation of the parasympathetic system typically leads to:

- Decreased heart rate  
- Increased digestive activity  
- Energy storage  
- Glandular secretion  
:::

> Decrease the `Arousal` level. These effects support recovery and homeostasis.

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_ANS.jpg){width="470" fig-align="right"}

::: 
::: 

## Major divisions of the brain

::: columns
::: column
From a broad anatomical perspective, the brain is divided into:

- Cerebrum (or Forebrain)
- Midbrain & Cerebellum
- Brainstem  (Hindbrain)

::: 
::: column

```{=html}
<iframe width="500" height="500" src=https://sketchfab.com/models/8108e55e45b842bb935c33141ca76789/embed title="Brain Anatomy"></iframe>
```

::: 
::: 

## The cerebrum

::: columns
::: column

The cerebrum is divided into two `hemispheres` (Left and Right)
The hemispheres are connected by large bundles of axons (`Corpus Callosum`).

::: info-box
It is responsible for:

- Sensory perception  
- Voluntary movement  
- Cognition and language  
- Conscious awareness  
:::

> Despite strong similarities, the two hemispheres are `not` functionally identical.

::: 
::: column


```{=html}
<iframe width="500" height="500" src=https://sketchfab.com/models/8108e55e45b842bb935c33141ca76789/embed title="Brain Anatomy"></iframe>
```

::: 
::: 

## Cerebral Cortex

::: columns
::: column

The outer layer of the cerebrum is the **cerebral cortex**.

::: info-box
Folding pattern

- `Gyri` Raised ridges of cortex
- `Sulci` Grooves that separate gyri

This pattern increase surface area without increasing volume.
:::

::: card
Each hemisphere is subdivided into lobes. The main lobes are:
[Frontal]{.highlight}, [Parietal]{.highlight}, [Temporal]{.highlight}, [Occipital]{.highlight} 
:::

::: 
::: column

```{=html}
<iframe width="500" height="500" src=https://sketchfab.com/models/8108e55e45b842bb935c33141ca76789/embed title="Brain Anatomy"></iframe>
```

::: 
::: 

## Frontal lobe

::: columns
::: column
The **frontal lobe** is located anterior to the `central sulcus`.

It is heavily involved in motor control and high-level cognition.

::: info-box
**Primary roles**

- Voluntary movement  
- Planning and decision making  
- Executive control
:::

::: info-box
**Effects of damage**

- Motor dysfunctions
- Changes in [personality and social behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phineas_Gage)   
:::

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_frontal.png){width="500" fig-align="right"}

::: 
::: 

## Parietal lobe

::: columns
::: column
The **parietal lobe** lies posterior to the central sulcus.
It integrates sensory information to construct `spatial and bodily representations`.

::: info-box
**Primary roles**

- Somatosensory processing  
- Spatial awareness (Propioception) 
- Integration of sensory modalities  
:::

::: info-box
**Effects of damage**

- Impaired touch perception   
- [Spatial Neglect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hemispatial_neglect), especially after right hemisphere damage
:::

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_parietal.png){width="500" fig-align="right"}

::: 
::: 

## Temporal lobe

::: columns
::: column
The **temporal lobe** is located laterally, beneath the lateral sulcus.
It is closely associated with auditory processing, memory, and emotion.

::: info-box
**Primary roles**

- Auditory perception  
- Language comprehension  
- [Memory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Molaison) & Emotional processing
:::

::: info-box
**Effects of damage**

- Auditory perception deficits  
- Impaired language comprehension  
- Memory & emotional disturbances   
:::

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_temporal.png){width="500" fig-align="right"}

::: 
::: 

## Occipital lobe

::: columns
::: column

The **occipital lobe** is located at the posterior pole of the brain.

It is primarily dedicated to visual processing.

::: info-box
**Primary roles**

- Visual perception  
- Processing of shape, motion, and color  
:::

::: info-box
**Effects of damage**

- Partial or complete loss of vision  
- Visual field deficits
:::

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_occipital.png){width="500" fig-align="right"}


::: 
::: 

## Subcortical structures

Below the Cerebral Cortex we can find also another layer of (Subcortical) structures. 

::: info-box
Major subcortical structures include:

- Basal nuclei  
- Hippocampus  
- Amygdala  
:::

They are not visible from the surface but are critical for information processing.

> They `interact` extensively with the cortex.

## Basal nuclei
::: columns
::: column
The **[basal nuclei]{.highlight}** are a group of interconnected nuclei. Including the `dorsal striatum` (caudate nucleus and putamen) and the `ventral striatum` (nucleus accumbens), the globus pallidus, the ventral pallidum, the substantia nigra, and the subthalamic nucleus.

:::info-box
They are best known for their role in:

- Movement regulation  
- Action selection  
- Habit formation  
:::

>Damage to these structures disrupts `movement` without causing paralysis.

:::
:::column
![](images/SN_org_basal_nuclei.jpg){width="500" fig-align="right"}
:::
:::

## Hippocampus

::: columns
::: column

The **hippocampus** is located in the `medial temporal lobe`.

:::info-box
It is essential for:

- Formation memory and Contextual processing 
- Spatial navigation  
- Emotional regulation
:::

> Damage may impair the ability to form new long-term `memories`.

::: 
::: column
![](images/SN_org_hippo_amy.jpg){width="500" fig-align="right"}
::: 
:::

## Amygdala

::: columns
::: column
The **amygdala** is also located in the `medial temporal lobe`.

:::info-box
It plays a major role in:

- Emotional processing  
- Threat detection  
- Assigning emotional value to stimuli  
:::

> Damage to this structure may strongly influence learning and memory under `emotional` conditions.

::: 
::: column
![](images/SN_org_hippo_amy.jpg){width="500" fig-align="right"}
::: 
::: 

## Diencephalon

::: columns
::: column
The **diencephalon** lies beneath the cerebrum.

It serves as a critical `interface` between cortical and subcortical systems.

Major components include:

- Thalamus  
- Hypothalamus  
- Epithalamus

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_dienc.png){width="500" fig-align="right"}

::: 
:::

## Thalamus

::: columns
::: column
The **thalamus** is often described as a `relay station`.

Most sensory information passes through it on the way to cortex.

> However, it is not a passive `relay`.
> It actively `shapes` and `modulates` information flow.

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_dienc.png){width="500" fig-align="right"}

::: 
::: 

## Hypothalamus

::: columns
::: column

The **hypothalamus** is a group of different nuclei, small but functionally powerful.

::: info-box
It regulates:

- Homeostasis  
- Autonomic nervous system activity  
- Hormone release  
- Motivated behaviors  
:::

> It forms a major `link` between the nervous and endocrine systems.

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_dienc.png){width="500" fig-align="right"}

::: 
::: 

## Brainstem

::: columns
::: column

The **brainstem** connects the brain to the spinal cord.

It is essential for `survival`.

::: info-box
It controls basic functions such as:

- Breathing  
- Heart rate  
- Sleep and arousal  
:::

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_brainstem.png){width="500" fig-align="right"}


::: 
::: 

## Brainstem subdivisions

::: columns
::: column

The brainstem is divided into three major parts:

::: info-box
- Midbrain  
- Pons  
- Medulla  
:::

> Each contains nuclei and pathways critical for life.

::: 
::: column
![](images/SN_org_brainstem.png){width="500" fig-align="right"}

::: 
::: 

## Cerebellum

::: columns
::: column

The **cerebellum** lies posterior to the brainstem.

::: info-box
It is involved in:

- Coordination of movement  
- Timing  
- Motor learning  
:::

> Damage does not prevent movement, but makes it inaccurate and unstable.

::: 
::: column
![](images/SN_org_cerebellum.jpg){width="500" fig-align="right"}

::: 
::: 

## Cranial nerves

Cranial nerves are part of the `peripheral nervous system`.
They connect directly to the brain. 

>Most cranial nerves enter or exit the CNS at the [brainstem]{.highlight} (except olfactory and optic nerves).

> There are **12 pairs of cranial nerves**. Numbered using Roman numerals I to XII .

:::info-box
Cranial nerves can be classified by function:

- **Sensory**  
- **Motor**  
- **Mixed** (sensory and motor)  
:::

## Cranial nerves

::: columns
::: column

| Sensory                                                      | Motor                                                            | Mixed                                                                       |
|--------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| [Olfactory I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olfactory_nerve) | [Oculomotor III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oculomotor_nerve) | [Trigeminal V](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trigeminal_nerve)              |
| [Optic II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optic_nerve)        | [Trochlear  IV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trochlear_nerve)   | [Facial VII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facial_nerve)                    |
| [Vestibulocochlear VII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vestibulocochlear_nerve) | [Abducens VI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abducens_nerve)      | [Glossopharyngeal IX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossopharyngeal_nerve) |
|                                                              | [Accessory  XI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accessory_nerve)   | [Vagus X](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vagus_nerve)                        |
|                                                              | [Hypoglossal XII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypoglossal_nerve)                                              |                                                                             |

:::info-box
The [Vagus nerve X]{.highlight} is unique.
It provides extensive `parasympathetic` innervation to thoracic and abdominal organs.
It is a major pathway for `autonomic` communication between `brain and body`.
:::

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_cranial_nerves.png){width="350" fig-align="right"}

## The spinal cord

The **spinal cord** is part of the central nervous system.
It serves as the main communication pathway between the brain and the body, through the spinal nerves.
It also performs important processing independently of the brain.

::: columns
::: column

> Grouped into regions: `Cervical`, `Thoracic`, `Lumbar`, `Sacral`  


::: info-box
Spinal nerves connect to the cord via two roots:

- [Dorsal root]{.highlight} Carries `sensory` information into the spinal cord  

- [Ventral root]{.highlight} Carries `motor` commands out of the spinal cord  
:::

::: 
::: column

![](images/SN_org_spinal_cord.jpg){width="500" fig-align="right"}

::: 
:::
